Tech + Identity Editorial Info

Wealthfront

Building an illustrative brand

Wealthfront is a financial services product that helps consumers make crucial investment decisions. Having never incorporated product illustrations in the app before, we worked together to build out the initial foundation to their illustration brand system and create 60+ illustrations for the product.

Starting blocks

As a tech company within the financial industry, Wealthfront wanted to position itself as a more relatable and human option to large institutions, but still connote the trustworthiness and seriouesness of a financial institution — quirky, yet reliable; clever, but understandable.

Starting out, we explored many visual tones that expressed these values in different ways, and these are some of the key directions that emerged. In particular, we really gravitated towards a modernist approach, in that it tied in a sense of playfulness and ownable quirkiness while still feeling grounded and traditional.

Using our original marks as a starting point, we then we able to finesse the style down, focusing on simplifying color, execution (vector vs. hand-drawn, geometric vs. slightly imperfect), and tone (texture, shading) to create an overall more readable and straightforward aesthetic. We liked how this approach could be grounded in solid, firm shapes but still have a quirky flair with an exagerrated gesture or leaf out of place!

Characters

One key part of developing an illustration system, particularly for a consumer-facing company, is figuring out what the characters look like within the world of the brand. Using the above exploration as a starting block, we refined the characters' design to be less "blocky" and more fluid, within a slightly more modern palette.

A lot can be expressed through simple stylized illustration guidelines. For instance, characters have high-waisted torsos (longer legs) and their feet are always standing on a plane (never flat), to convey a sense of constant forward movement and energy.

Characters are also intentionally abstracted, using the minimal number of geometric, angular shapes needed to express movement and personality!

Because this abstracted stylization, characters can also interact with simplified shapes borrowed from the UI to demonstrate complex financial topics.


Metaphors, character, & voice

When it came to extending this voice to an illustration library, we didn't want to fall back on literal, obvious imagery to convey these financial concepts (eg. piggybanks or actual stacks of money).

As such, we created a series of metaphors to represent each central concept — for instance, plants represent money, and a series of growing plants represents an increase in a consumer's investment accounts.

We also sought to use a very human and warm tone to expressing these concepts, and found that without characters, some of these visuals came off looking too cold or stock - as such, our overall set is very character-driven.

With this foundation, we extended the visual language to concepts ranging from investing 101, managing and growing your accounts, to the automatic tax-saving benefits that Wealthfront offers.

To humanize the complicated automized technical back-end behind Wealthfront's services, we created a series of fun Rube-Goldberg inspired metaphors behind some of these automated investing concepts.

Building the system

With these pieces, we extended our illustration brand into a full system: a set of metaphorically consistent icons, grids and backgrounds for print collateral, and illustrations to launch within the product.

Extending the system

After my involvement in setting the foundation for the brand, the team did an amazing job extending out and growing the system. The below assets were created afterwards by the Wealthfront design team, and are a great example of how a flexible illustration system can be extended and developed.
